"https://www.americanoceans.org/facts/types-of-sturgeon/", "content": "White Sturgeon\nScientific Name: Acipenser transmontanus Other Names: Pacific sturgeon Size: Up to 20 feet long and weighing up estuaries of the western United States and Canada.\n Shortnose Sturgeon\nScientific Name: Acipenser brevirostrum Other Names: Eastern sturgeon, Connecticut River sturgeon Size: Up to 4 feet long and weighing up to 50 pounds Distribution: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida\nThe Shortnose sturgeon is a small, bottom-dwelling fish that can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the eastern United States.\n Green Sturgeon\nScientific Name: Acipenser medirostris Other Names: Southern sturgeon Size: Up to 7 feet long and weighing up to 350 pounds Sturgeons can be found in subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America, with the greatest diversity in Eurasia.score?Ⱦԫraw_contenttitleK15 Types of Sturgeon: Fish Species That Have Survived ... - American Oceansurl7https://www.americanoceans.org/facts/types-of-sturgeon/contentWhite Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser transmontanus Other Names: Pacific sturgeon Size: Up to 20 feet long and weighing up to 1,800 pounds Distribution: Found on the west coast of North America, from Mexico to Alaska
The White sturgeon is the largest freshwater fish in North America and can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the western United States and Canada.
 Shortnose Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser brevirostrum Other Names: Eastern sturgeon, Connecticut River sturgeon Size: Up to 4 feet long and weighing up to 50 pounds Distribution: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida
The Shortnose sturgeon is a small, bottom-dwelling fish that can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the eastern United States.
 Green Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser medirostris Other Names: Southern sturgeon Size: Up to 7 feet long and weighing up to 350 pounds Distribution: Found along the west coast of North America, from Mexico to Alaska
The Green sturgeon is a large, bottom-dwelling fish that can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the western United States and Canada.
 Sterlet Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser ruthenus Other Names: None Size: Up to 3 feet long and weighing up to 20 pounds Distribution: Found in the Danube River and its tributaries
The Sterlet sturgeon is a small freshwater fish that can be found in the Danube River and its tributaries in Europe.
 Amur sturgeon, Heilongjiang sturgeon Size: Up to 10 feet long and weighing up to 500 pounds Distribution: Found in the Yangtze River and its tributaries
The Chinese sturgeon is a large freshwater fish that can be found in the Yangtze River and its tributaries in China.

Sturgeon Conservation Society
Contact: The Center's Bay-Delta
Campaign  is aimed at protecting the green sturgeon's deteriorating
habitat in the San Francisco Bay-Delta; we're leading efforts to reduce the use
of pesticides that run off into the Delta; and we're working with allies to
force the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation to provide adequate passage for green
sturgeon over the Red Bluff Diversion Dam into the habitat they need to spawn
in the upper Sacramento.
 Because sturgeon are highly vulnerable to overfishing, and fisheries for
green sturgeon have depleted the stocks of large, old fish that are essential
for spawning, the states of California, Oregon, and Washington restricted sport
fishing of green sturgeon after federal protection was established. SAVING THE NORTH AMERICAN GREEN STURGEON
The San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system are home
to a rare, enormous species of living fossil called the green sturgeon. Among the
largest, longest-living fish in freshwater, sturgeon can reach seven feet long,
weigh 350 pounds and survive to be 70.

green sturgeon have depleted the stocks of large, old fish that are essential
for spawning, the states of California, Oregon, and Washington restricted sport
fishing of green sturgeon after federal protection was established. SAVING THE NORTH AMERICAN GREEN STURGEON
The San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system are home
to a rare, enormous species of living fossil called the green sturgeon. Among the
largest, longest-living fish in freshwater, sturgeon can reach seven feet long,

results.title: Sturgeons - Encyclopedia of Arkansas
results.content: There are about twenty-five species of sturgeons, and all belong to the Family Acipenseridae, Order Acipenseriformes. Sturgeons can be found in subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America, with the greatest diversity in Eurasia.

results.title: 15 Types of Sturgeon: Fish Species That Have Survived ... - American Oceans
results.content:
White Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser transmontanus Other Names: Pacific sturgeon Size: Up to 20 feet long and weighing up to 1,800 pounds Distribution: Found on the west coast of North America, from Mexico to Alaska
The White sturgeon is the largest freshwater fish in North America and can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the western United States and Canada.
 Shortnose Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser brevirostrum Other Names: Eastern sturgeon, Connecticut River sturgeon Size: Up to 4 feet long and weighing up to 50 pounds Distribution: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida
The Shortnose sturgeon is a small, bottom-dwelling fish that can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the eastern United States.
 Green Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser medirostris Other Names: Southern sturgeon Size: Up to 7 feet long and weighing up to 350 pounds Distribution: Found along the west coast of North America, from Mexico to Alaska
The Green sturgeon is a large, bottom-dwelling fish that can be found in the rivers and estuaries of the western United States and Canada.
 Sterlet Sturgeon
Scientific Name: Acipenser ruthenus Other Names: None Size: Up to 3 feet long and weighing up to 20 pounds Distribution: Found in the Danube River and its tributaries
The Sterlet sturgeon is a small freshwater fish that can be found in the Danube River and its tributaries in Europe.
 Amur sturgeon, Heilongjiang sturgeon Size: Up to 10 feet long and weighing up to 500 pounds Distribution: Found in the Yangtze River and its tributaries
The Chinese sturgeon is a large freshwater fish that can be found in the Yangtze River and its tributaries in China.

Contact: The Center's Bay-Delta
Campaign  is aimed at protecting the green sturgeon's deteriorating
habitat in the San Francisco Bay-Delta; we're leading efforts to reduce the use
of pesticides that run off into the Delta; and we're working with allies to
force the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation to provide adequate passage for green
sturgeon over the Red Bluff Diversion Dam into the habitat they need to spawn
in the upper Sacramento.
 Because sturgeon are highly vulnerable to overfishing, and fisheries for
green sturgeon have depleted the stocks of large, old fish that are essential
for spawning, the states of California, Oregon, and Washington restricted sport
fishing of green sturgeon after federal protection was established. SAVING THE NORTH AMERICAN GREEN STURGEON
The San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system are home
to a rare, enormous species of living fossil called the green sturgeon. Among the
largest, longest-living fish in freshwater, sturgeon can reach seven feet long,
weigh 350 pounds and survive to be 70.

langchain_core.messages.aiAIMessagecontent_# Research Report on North American Sturgeon

## Introduction
Sturgeons are ancient fish belonging to the family Acipenseridae and are found in subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America. These species are known for their long lifespans and large sizes, and they play critical roles in their respective ecosystems. This report provides an overview of several notable North American sturgeon species, their habitats, and conservation efforts.

## Major Species of North American Sturgeon

### 1. **White Sturgeon (Acipenser transmontanus)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 20 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the west coast of North America, ranging from Mexico to Alaska.
- **Habitat**: Inhabit rivers and estuaries; known for being the largest freshwater fish in North America.

### 2. **Shortnose Sturgeon (Acipenser brevirostrum)**
- **Size**: Typically reaches 4 feet in length and up to 50 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida.
- **Habitat**: Bottom-dwelling fish found in rivers and estuaries.

### 3. **Green Sturgeon (Acipenser medirostris)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 7 feet long and weigh up to 350 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found from Mexico to Alaska along the west coast.
- **Habitat**: Inhabits rivers and estuaries; recognized for its large size and long lifespan.

## Conservation and Threats
Sturgeons are highly vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation. For instance, the green sturgeon is protected under the Endangered Species Act, with efforts concentrated in the San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system. Conservation actions include habitat protection, reducing pesticide runoff, and ensuring passage over barriers like the Red Bluff Diversion Dam.

## Chart: Overview of North American Sturgeon Species

| Species             | Maximum Length | Maximum Weight | Distribution                        | Key Habitat Feature          |
|---------------------|----------------|----------------|-------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| White Sturgeon      | 20 feet        | 1,800 pounds   | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Largest freshwater fish      |
| Shortnose Sturgeon  | 4 feet         | 50 pounds      | East Coast (New Brunswick to Florida)| Bottom-dwelling              |
| Green Sturgeon      | 7 feet         | 350 pounds     | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Long-living "living fossil"  |

## Conclusion

kwargs.content:
# Research Report on North American Sturgeon

## Introduction
Sturgeons are ancient fish belonging to the family Acipenseridae and are found in subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America. These species are known for their long lifespans and large sizes, and they play critical roles in their respective ecosystems. This report provides an overview of several notable North American sturgeon species, their habitats, and conservation efforts.

## Major Species of North American Sturgeon

### 1. **White Sturgeon (Acipenser transmontanus)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 20 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the west coast of North America, ranging from Mexico to Alaska.
- **Habitat**: Inhabit rivers and estuaries; known for being the largest freshwater fish in North America.

### 2. **Shortnose Sturgeon (Acipenser brevirostrum)**
- **Size**: Typically reaches 4 feet in length and up to 50 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida.
- **Habitat**: Bottom-dwelling fish found in rivers and estuaries.

### 3. **Green Sturgeon (Acipenser medirostris)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 7 feet long and weigh up to 350 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found from Mexico to Alaska along the west coast.
- **Habitat**: Inhabits rivers and estuaries; recognized for its large size and long lifespan.

## Conservation and Threats
Sturgeons are highly vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation. For instance, the green sturgeon is protected under the Endangered Species Act, with efforts concentrated in the San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system. Conservation actions include habitat protection, reducing pesticide runoff, and ensuring passage over barriers like the Red Bluff Diversion Dam.

## Chart: Overview of North American Sturgeon Species

| Species             | Maximum Length | Maximum Weight | Distribution                        | Key Habitat Feature          |
|---------------------|----------------|----------------|-------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| White Sturgeon      | 20 feet        | 1,800 pounds   | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Largest freshwater fish      |
| Shortnose Sturgeon  | 4 feet         | 50 pounds      | East Coast (New Brunswick to Florida)| Bottom-dwelling              |
| Green Sturgeon      | 7 feet         | 350 pounds     | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Long-living "living fossil"  |

## Conclusion
North American sturgeons are remarkable for their size and longevity, but face significant threats from human activities. Conservation efforts are crucial to protect these ancient species and maintain their ecological roles in aquatic ecosystems. Continued research and habitat protection are necessary to ensure their survival for future generations.

langchain_core.messages.humanHumanMessagecontent# Research Report on North American Sturgeon

## Introduction
Sturgeons are ancient fish belonging to the family Acipenseridae. They are distributed throughout subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America. Known for their long lifespans, large sizes, and critical roles in their ecosystems, sturgeons are fascinating species worthy of study and conservation efforts.

## Major Species of North American Sturgeon

### 1. **White Sturgeon (Acipenser transmontanus)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 20 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the west coast of North America, ranging from Mexico to Alaska.
- **Habitat**: Inhabit rivers and estuaries; known for being the largest freshwater fish in North America.

### 2. **Shortnose Sturgeon (Acipenser brevirostrum)**
- **Size**: Typically reaches 4 feet in length and up to 50 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida.
- **Habitat**: Bottom-dwelling fish found in rivers and estuaries.

### 3. **Green Sturgeon (Acipenser medirostris)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 7 feet long and weigh up to 350 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found from Mexico to Alaska along the west coast.
- **Habitat**: Inhabits rivers and estuaries; recognized for its large size and long lifespan.

## Conservation and Threats
Sturgeons are highly vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation. For instance, the green sturgeon is protected under the Endangered Species Act, with efforts concentrated in the San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system. Conservation actions include habitat protection, reducing pesticide runoff, and ensuring passage over barriers like the Red Bluff Diversion Dam.

## Chart: Overview of North American Sturgeon Species

| Species             | Maximum Length | Maximum Weight | Distribution                        | Key Habitat Feature          |
|---------------------|----------------|----------------|-------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| White Sturgeon      | 20 feet        | 1,800 pounds   | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Largest freshwater fish      |
| Shortnose Sturgeon  | 4 feet         | 50 pounds      | East Coast (New Brunswick to Florida)| Bottom-dwelling              |
| Green Sturgeon      | 7 feet         | 350 pounds     | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Long-living "living fossil"  |

## Conclusion
North American sturgeons are remarkable for their size and longevity but face significant threats from human activities. Conservation efforts are crucial to protect these ancient species and maintain their ecological roles in aquatic ecosystems. Continued research and habitat protection are necessary to ensure their survival for future generations.additional_kwargsresponse_metadatatypehumannameid$e1b238b0-ccd5-4734-a73c-0ecf4249324aexample³model_validate_json

langchain_core.messages.humanHumanMessagecontent# Research Report on North American Sturgeon

## Introduction
Sturgeons are ancient fish belonging to the family Acipenseridae. They are distributed throughout subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America. Known for their long lifespans, large sizes, and critical roles in their ecosystems, sturgeons are fascinating species worthy of study and conservation efforts.

## Major Species of North American Sturgeon

### 1. **White Sturgeon (Acipenser transmontanus)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 20 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the west coast of North America, ranging from Mexico to Alaska.
- **Habitat**: Inhabit rivers and estuaries; known for being the largest freshwater fish in North America.

### 2. **Shortnose Sturgeon (Acipenser brevirostrum)**
- **Size**: Typically reaches 4 feet in length and up to 50 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida.
- **Habitat**: Bottom-dwelling fish found in rivers and estuaries.

### 3. **Green Sturgeon (Acipenser medirostris)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 7 feet long and weigh up to 350 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found from Mexico to Alaska along the west coast.
- **Habitat**: Inhabits rivers and estuaries; recognized for its large size and long lifespan.

## Conservation and Threats
Sturgeons are highly vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation. For instance, the green sturgeon is protected under the Endangered Species Act, with efforts concentrated in the San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system. Conservation actions include habitat protection, reducing pesticide runoff, and ensuring passage over barriers like the Red Bluff Diversion Dam.

## Chart: Overview of North American Sturgeon Species

| Species             | Maximum Length | Maximum Weight | Distribution                        | Key Habitat Feature          |
|---------------------|----------------|----------------|-------------------------------------|------------------------------|
| White Sturgeon      | 20 feet        | 1,800 pounds   | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Largest freshwater fish      |
| Shortnose Sturgeon  | 4 feet         | 50 pounds      | East Coast (New Brunswick to Florida)| Bottom-dwelling              |
| Green Sturgeon      | 7 feet         | 350 pounds     | West Coast (Mexico to Alaska)       | Long-living "living fossil"  |

## Conclusion
North American sturgeons are remarkable for their size and longevity but face significant threats from human activities. Conservation efforts are crucial to protect these ancient species and maintain their ecological roles in aquatic ecosystems. Continued research and habitat protection are necessary to ensure their survival for future generations.additional_kwargsresponse_metadatatypehumannameWebScraperidexample³model_validate_json

langchain_core.messages.humanHumanMessagecontent# Research Report on North American Sturgeon

## Introduction
Sturgeons are ancient fish belonging to the family Acipenseridae. They are distributed throughout subtropical, temperate, and sub-Arctic rivers, lakes, and coastlines of North America. Known for their long lifespans, large sizes, and critical roles in their ecosystems, sturgeons are fascinating species worthy of study and conservation efforts.

## Major Species of North American Sturgeon

### 1. **White Sturgeon (Acipenser transmontanus)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 20 feet long and weigh up to 1,800 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the west coast of North America, ranging from Mexico to Alaska.
- **Habitat**: Inhabit rivers and estuaries; known for being the largest freshwater fish in North America.

### 2. **Shortnose Sturgeon (Acipenser brevirostrum)**
- **Size**: Typically reaches 4 feet in length and up to 50 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found along the eastern coast of North America, from New Brunswick to Florida.
- **Habitat**: Bottom-dwelling fish found in rivers and estuaries.

### 3. **Green Sturgeon (Acipenser medirostris)**
- **Size**: Can grow up to 7 feet long and weigh up to 350 pounds.
- **Distribution**: Found from Mexico to Alaska along the west coast.
- **Habitat**: Inhabits rivers and estuaries; recognized for its large size and long lifespan.

## Conservation and Threats
Sturgeons are highly vulnerable to overfishing and habitat degradation. For instance, the green sturgeon is protected under the Endangered Species Act, with efforts concentrated in the San Francisco Bay-Delta and Sacramento-San Joaquin river system. Conservation actions include habitat protection, reducing pesticide runoff, and ensuring passage over barriers like the Red Bluff Diversion Dam.
